channel.title: [NEW] Fixing a laptop Hard drive?
channel.description:
[s]Okay, before the title misleads you, I do not need to pay for windows 8 keys. My teachers is a part of MSDN (Microsoft Developer Network) and can get lists of keys (He gave me the extra's to the set of win7's he had). I've got 3 computers, all running windows 7 currently. My Career tech school (where ^ teacher is) has already updated to windows 8, we spent 2 weeks doing so, and I don't like hopping between the two, as 8 is so much different than 7. The real question is, Software and performance wise, is windows 8 worth the install?
Edit: I'm really bad at asking questions. I get side tracked a lot.. Sorry.[/s]
The above shit is old and worthless.
So my friend did something to her laptop, I have no clue what. She told me she deleted the OS on it while drunk, but I feel there was more done than that. I have a windows 7 boot disc, and some linux ones. I also have a USB that I can put Windows 8, and just about any Linux os on it. First, I put windows 8 on the USB and tried running it. It got to the after I clicked install (to just re-install a new OS), it froze at "Start up is setting up" or what ever. Okay, so I quit and tried the repair computer option. That froze as well. I decided to try my Ubuntu disc, and it loaded, but it wouldn't load the installer past where it checks if you have internet, power, and 4.4gbs of hard drive space. Then I tried active@ killdisk. You guessed it; that froze too. I cannot access the physical hard drive because it's a Dell Inspiron 3520 and the entire bottom is sealed. There's no panel to open the hard drive. What do I do in a situation like this? -Aside from tell my friend you're S.O.L or to go see an expert. I want a solution I could try.

item.title: [NEW] Fixing a laptop Hard drive?
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:31, topic:518598”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=636864.msg4295966#msg4295966 date=1368227763]
I don’t know what she did. All I was told was it’s broken and she supposedly deleted the OS.
Oh, yeah, she did say she threw it once. There’s also scratches on the top of the laptop, so obvious damage is there.
There’s nothing on the drive and it can’t even be formatted etc.
[/quote]
Honestly I doubt she deleted the OS, it’s pretty bloody hard to do so really, you’d have to either use a command line program such as diskpart and have a decent amount of command line knowledge, or boot into another OS and delete from there, I mean who the hell does that when they’re drunk?!

Much more likely she got angry with it or something (drunken short temperedness) and either hit it or threw it, it’ll have to be a hard drive replacement.[/quote]Maybe she found out about the other lady?

but as CJ has stated you are better off just getting a new HD. Not much you can do to repair it by the looks of the results.

Read full topic

item.title: [NEW] Fixing a laptop Hard drive?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:34, topic:518598”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=636864.msg4295981#msg4295981 date=1368230217]

I don’t know what she did. All I was told was it’s broken and she supposedly deleted the OS.
Oh, yeah, she did say she threw it once. There’s also scratches on the top of the laptop, so obvious damage is there.
There’s nothing on the drive and it can’t even be formatted etc.

Honestly I doubt she deleted the OS, it’s pretty bloody hard to do so really, you’d have to either use a command line program such as diskpart and have a decent amount of command line knowledge, or boot into another OS and delete from there, I mean who the hell does that when they’re drunk?!

Much more likely she got angry with it or something (drunken short temperedness) and either hit it or threw it, it’ll have to be a hard drive replacement.

I threw a spare of mine in that was like 100GBs. But there’s no fix for the hard drive otherwise?
[/quote]
Nope, you may still be able to use it occasionally as just a large memory stick, but I wouldn’t use it for the OS or anything important[/quote]
It wouldn’t even do that lol. Nothing can write to the drive.
You can lock this though, thanks for the help.

Read full topic

Honestly I doubt she deleted the OS, it’s pretty bloody hard to do so really, you’d have to either use a command line program such as diskpart and have a decent amount of command line knowledge, or boot into another OS and delete from there, I mean who the hell does that when they’re drunk?!

Much more likely she got angry with it or something (drunken short temperedness) and either hit it or threw it, it’ll have to be a hard drive replacement.
[/quote]
I threw a spare of mine in that was like 100GBs. But there’s no fix for the hard drive otherwise?[/quote]
Nope, you may still be able to use it occasionally as just a large memory stick, but I wouldn’t use it for the OS or anything important

item.title: [NEW] Fixing a laptop Hard drive?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:29, topic:518598”]Yeah, fitness is 0%, it could completely die at any minute so I’d suggest copying everything you need from it before it does so, then look at getting a replacement, if it’s under warranty then go down that route.

Did she drop it at all by any chance?

It’d be worth trying a full wipe (if possible) and then try reinstalling etc, but judging from my couple of dead HDDs in the past it’s likely unfixable.[/quote]
I don’t know what she did. All I was told was it’s broken and she supposedly deleted the OS.
Oh, yeah, she did say she threw it once. There’s also scratches on the top of the laptop, so obvious damage is there.
There’s nothing on the drive and it can’t even be formatted etc.

Read full topic

item.title: [NEW] Fixing a laptop Hard drive?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Yeah, fitness is 0%, it could completely die at any minute so I’d suggest copying everything you need from it before it does so, then look at getting a replacement, if it’s under warranty then go down that route.

Did she drop it at all by any chance?

It’d be worth trying a full wipe (if possible) and then try reinstalling etc, but judging from my couple of dead HDDs in the past it’s likely unfixable.

Read full topic

item.title: [NEW] Fixing a laptop Hard drive?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Okay this is what I got when I did their online test:

BLOCKING ISSUE : your hard disk has 34 pending sectors. Those are sectors that couldn't be properly read and that the hard disk logic is waiting for a write operation to try to remap to a spare sector (if available). According to the Reallocated Sector Count attribute, your hard disk seems to have available spare sectors. A simple disk surface scan won't be enough to force the remap operation. You need a read/write surface scan to remap the sector. The best option should be a tool that knows about what should be read from that sector so that it has some option to apply the best fix to the missing data.

The overall fitness for this drive is 0%.
The overall performance for this drive is 98%.

The link to get back and see a new report about this hard disk in the future is this. Consider that new hard disks and new checks are added over time.

and then there’s this:

Don’t know what Current Pending sector does… But it’s broken.

Read full topic

item.title: [NEW] Fixing a laptop Hard drive?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:24, topic:518598”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=636864.msg4295651#msg4295651 date=1368169702]
SMART test it, sounds dodgy. Speedfan has one built in if you haven’t got one handy.
[/quote]
What?[/quote]
S.M.A.R.T. test it, it’s a hard drive test used to determine the health and performance of a hard drive, it’ll tell you if the drive is failing (which seems likely from what you’ve said).

If you download the program ‘Speedfan’ it has a built in tester that’ll help you do this, the program just runs in Windows.

Read full topic

item.title: [NEW] Fixing a laptop Hard drive?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:21, topic:518598”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=636864.msg4294607#msg4294607 date=1367982846]
So I took the drive out of the computer, and I ran it via USB on my computer. I looked at it through Windows Disk Management, and it looked fine. I attempted to format and partition the drive (just to see what it’d do) and it said it couldn’t be partitioned. Don’t know why.
[/quote]
Use the GParted application in Ubuntu (live cd also has it if you don’t have it installed), guaranteed it’ll format anything.

Must’ve been a wild night for a girl to wipe her own OS[/quote]
That’s what I’m saying
and I’ll run Ubuntu here shortly.
EDIT:
Here’s the error for partitioning.
Input/Output error during write on /dev/sda

Edit2:
I plugged the drive back into Windows, and partitioned it to V:
and it gave this error when trying to use windows CMD to change to it via change directory (cd):

Data error: (cyclic redundancy check)

Edit3: No, I cannot run chkdsk on windows because apparently the data is RAW.

Read full topic

item.title: [NEW] Fixing a laptop Hard drive?
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

sk8rdude461:

So I took the drive out of the computer, and I ran it via USB on my computer. I looked at it through Windows Disk Management, and it looked fine. I attempted to format and partition the drive (just to see what it’d do) and it said it couldn’t be partitioned. Don’t know why.

Use the GParted application in Ubuntu (live cd also has it if you don’t have it installed), guaranteed it’ll format anything.

Must’ve been a wild night for a girl to wipe her own OS

Read full topic

item.title: [NEW] Fixing a laptop Hard drive?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:19, topic:518598”]Well your first problem is that it is a Dell lol.

But sadly I can’t see the screen from that vid sorry :s[/quote]
It’s not my computer. I told the girl that was getting it to have me tag-along.
And sorry. I don’t know how else to show it.
It’s something with the hard drive, that’s all I can point out right now.

Update:
So I took the drive out of the computer, and I ran it via USB on my computer. I looked at it through Windows Disk Management, and it looked fine. I attempted to format and partition the drive (just to see what it’d do) and it said it couldn’t be partitioned. Don’t know why.

Read full topic

I remember having a similar issue before with some other sort of hardware a long time ago. I downloaded some sort of application that went out there and helped to get what I needed.[/quote]

[youtube]http://youtu.be/m_OKYgUF7Ng[/youtube]
All windows installers freeze at one point.
Ignore the music. I was just covering background noise.

Also:
it says “the creation of swap space in partition failed” and there’s more tech stuff but I didn’t copy it, upon attempt to install Ubuntu.

item.title: [NEW] Fixing a laptop Hard drive?
item.dc:creator: @Cruel_Truth Cruel Truth
item.description:
@Cruel_Truth wrote:

It really depends on how much memory you have(I assume we talking multimedia performance not gaming)

Windows 7 -> 1gb memory
Windows 8 -> 2gb memory

The average desktop holds 8gb in today’s society so you should be alright. For professional software such as sony vegas and etc… well yeah have a processor/8gb and you will be fine I would imagine.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Soulcist:

It looked complicated as Hell to me and never was interested in attempting to try it, I’m thinking that I wouldn’t loose much if I installed it on this computer for the time being.

I don’t like that they made it oriented to touch screens. When ever I plug in a new usb device at my school, a thing pops up in the top right saying “Tap or click to…” Really? You couldn’t have a prompt asking if this was a touchscreen device or not?

item.title: [NEW] Fixing a laptop Hard drive?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

RSCShadow:

Most of those performance “benefits” are probably negligible. If you really want decreased boot time and app loading, invest in a SSD. Just use what you’re comfortable with.

I’ve got ~20 bucks to my name as of now. I don’t think a SSD is in my budget.

Rodgerwilco:

Windows 8 is superior.

That’s what it’s looking like

Read full topic
